I say near term because investigating each and every company takes time and resources; besides reducing efficiency, it might mean that by the time you find the connections it will be too late. Sometimes you have to take a short cut. It's fine to say that short cuts should not be taken at the expense of rights, but what rights are we walking about? The rights of corporations? Foreign corporations, at that? The right to our business? US citizens have a right of free speech. Foreign companies do not have a right of access to US markets. That's an abuse of "rights" as a concept. I'm no xenophobe, I believe in open borders and I think it would be wrong to use national trade policy for purely venal reasons, but I see no reason not to use such policy to serve higher interests.
 
 The long-term issue is a bit more abstract. The purpose of embargo is to exert pressure on a government not for a specific action but for creating an environment (e.g. via lax enforcement of laws) which leads to actions that harm the embargo initiator. It's supposed to work indirectly, by creating pressure on foreign individuals and companies so that they in turn will create pressure on their government. If the scope of an embargo is limited to companies with already-proven ties to terrorism (or whatever other ill we seek to avoid) then the pressure on that government will be negligible. Embargo thus becomes useless as a tool of statecraft, and nations would therefore turn to even less palatable means of preserving their safety or interests. Witness the abandonment of embargo for war in Iraq as an example. Without the leverage that embargo provides, we all lose.
 
 Embargo might not be anyone's cup of tea (yes that's a Boston reference) but it does serve a purpose and has to be evaluated against other means that might be used to serve those same purposes. It's like the old saying that democracy is a terrible way to govern . . . except for all the others that have been tried.
